channel.title: [TuT] How to Manipulate a Primitive [TuT]
channel.description:
This tutorial is to help people make a model out of a primitive, hope it helps! :)
Reference Picture:
[img]http://i606.photobucket.com/albums/tt145/geof103/sword_glamdringlarge.jpg[/img]
Step 1: Select the primitive you would like to start with and click on the Pers option to change it to Ortho.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/1.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/2.jpg[/img]
Step 2: Scale your primitive to a rectangle using the red, blue and green cubes then click create.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/3.jpg[/img]
Step 3: Before you manipulate the primitive you might need a reference picture, if not skip to step 5. Click on BkImg to add your reference picture in, and then Load one.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/4.jpg[/img]
Step 4: After loading your picture click the Img button up the top to display it.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/5.jpg[/img]
Step 5: Now unselect you Fc button and select your Ln button, this will show the wireframe of your rectangle.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/6.jpg[/img]
Step 6: With the rectangle you need to scale it so it will be the size of the blade, so click Sel Obj and then Scale.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/7.jpg[/img]
Step 7: Use your red X scale cube to lengthen the rectangle, with the blue Z scale cube you're going to thin the rectangle.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/8.jpg[/img]
Step 8: Once you are happy with the shape of your primitive you are going to use your Knife tool to cut it down the middle, it helps to use the Shift key while doing this to get a straight line.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/9.jpg[/img]
Step 9: You now need to make out your basic points to shape the rectangle; you do this using the Knife tool.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/10.jpg[/img]
Step 10: Using the Rope tool you're going to shape your primitive, it may help to put your Pt setting on.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/11.jpg[/img]
Step 11: Now that you have the basic outline of the blade you'll need to get the detail added. You do this by making 2 knife cuts into one half of your shape; you might need to rescale it first.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/12.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/12-2.jpg[/img]
Step 12: After scaling your primitive back to the right size you'll need to move the 2 cuts you just made to fit the detail of the sword. Use your Rope and Move tool to do this.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/13.jpg[/img]
Step 13: You'll have a few untidy areas, fix them up by roping the points and press Ctrl + J to join them together (watchout for the points under the ones on top, remember it is a 3d model). After doing this it should look like this.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/14.jpg[/img]
Step 14: Delete the half of the model you haven't been working on, use the Rope tool to select one side then press your Delete button.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/15.jpg[/img]
Step 15: You will now need to select the line in the middle of your model, use your Rope tool to get each part. Because the model is rather big you may need to hold Shift like roping to select more then 1 part at a time.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/16.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/17.jpg[/img]
Step 16: Once you've selected your faces you need to extrude them, do this by pressing Ctrl + E. Change the Offset to 1.00 and untick Select side.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/18.jpg[/img]
Step 17: Now that you've extruded the faces you'll need to scale them so they're smaller then the ones underneath, Use your Scale tool to scale the line on top.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/19.jpg[/img]
Step 18: Once you finish that you need to fix up any parts that do not fit the picture's blade.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/20.jpg[/img]
Step 20: Now you need to get the other side of the model, you do this by clicking Sel Obj and then going to selected. Go to mirror and then 3 settings will show up, click on XY option.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/21.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/21-2.jpg[/img]
Step 21: You now have 2 sides of a model which you need to connect, use Ctrl + J to join them (keep in mind the points below). If you feel more comfortable with deleting the bottom half of the model you should do so, after joining the points your model should look like this.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/22.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/22-2.jpg[/img]
Step 22: Move your view so your model is facing like this, then with your rope tool select the middle line of the model. With your Move tool lower this line.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/23.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/23-2.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/23-3.jpg[/img]
Step 23: Now we need the other side of the model, so Sel Obj and Mirror but this time select the ZX option.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/24.jpg[/img]
Step 24: you now have 2 sides and you'll have to join them together using your joining tool (Ctrl + J).
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/25.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/26.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/26-2.jpg[/img]
Step 25: Use your scale tool to make your model thinner, from the side you need to select the model and scale it.
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/27.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/27-2.jpg[/img]
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/27-3.jpg[/img]
That is how to model the blade; from there you model the handle using the same tools to manipulate your primitive.
Finished model:
[IMG]http://i1183.photobucket.com/albums/x470/0acer0/TuT/28.jpg[/img]
[url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,497190.msg3635492.html#msg3635492]How to colour models.[/url]
